p: Of the 661 patients with acute HEV infection, 483 (73%) resided in rural areas, 486 (74%) were male; their median age was 25 years (IQR: 20â€“33). Acute hepatitis E prevalence varied across the hospital sites, ranging from 17% in Sylhet to 61% in Dhaka ( Table 1). Among the patients with acute jaundice, those who were male, aged between 20 to 39 years, resided in urban areas, educated, or whose monthly family expenditure was >15,000 takas (US$188) were more likely to have acute HEV infection (p<0.001). Acute HEV infection was higher among the pregnant women with acute jaundice than the non-pregnant women with acute jaundice (39% vs. 24%, p<0.001). The higher rate of acute HEV infection among educated and higher income group patients with acute jaundice in the study hospitals was consistent in the analysis by rural-urban area of residence ( S3 Table).
